javascript.title: Declaring variables: var, let, const & Temporal Dead Zone
javascript.content:
In JavaScript, variables can be declared using var, let, and const. Each has its own scope, hoisting behavior, and usage rules:

  • var: Function-scoped. It is hoisted and initialized with undefined. Accessing it before declaration does not throw an error but returns undefined. Example: console.log(a); var a = 10; // undefined
  • let: Block-scoped. Resides in the Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) from the start of its block until the declaration is evaluated. Accessing it before declaration throws a ReferenceError. Example: console.log(b); let b = 20; // ReferenceError
  • const: Block-scoped and also resides in the TDZ. Must be initialized at declaration and cannot be reassigned. Example: const c = 30; c = 40; // TypeError

Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ): The phase between entering a scope and the actual declaration of let or const. During this phase, the variables exist but cannot be accessed. TDZ helps prevent accidental access to uninitialized variables, improving code safety.

Summary:

  • var: function-scoped, hoisted, initialized with undefined
  • let: block-scoped, hoisted, uninitialized in TDZ
  • const: block-scoped, hoisted, uninitialized in TDZ, must be assigned at declaration, cannot be reassigned

examples.code:
console.log(a);
var a = 10;
examples.description: Variable declared with 'var' is hoisted; outputs undefined.
examples.whyItHappens: 'var' declarations are hoisted with default value undefined, so accessing before assignment doesn't throw an error.

examples.code:
console.log(b);
let b = 20;
examples.description: Variable declared with 'let' is in Temporal Dead Zone; throws ReferenceError.
examples.whyItHappens: 'let' is block-scoped and not initialized until the line is executed, creating a TDZ.

examples.code:
const c = 30;
c = 40;
examples.description: Cannot reassign a 'const' variable; throws TypeError.
examples.whyItHappens: 'const' must be initialized and cannot be reassigned after declaration.

javascript.title: Equality operators (== vs ===)
javascript.content: '==' is the abstract equality operator, which compares values after type coercion. '===' is the strict equality operator, which compares both value and type without coercion. Using '===' avoids unexpected type conversions and is generally recommended.

examples.description: Abstract equality allows type coercion; returns true.
examples.whyItHappens: JavaScript converts the string '5' to number 5 before comparison.

examples.description: Strict equality compares value and type; returns false.
examples.whyItHappens: Number and string types are different; no coercion happens.

examples.code:
null == undefined;
null === undefined;
examples.description: Abstract equality: true, Strict equality: false
examples.whyItHappens: '==' considers null and undefined equal, but '===' checks type as well.

javascript.title: Spread (...) and rest parameters
javascript.content: The spread operator '...' expands iterable elements like arrays or objects into individual elements. Rest parameters '...' collect multiple arguments into an array. Spread is used in function calls, array/object copying, or merging. Rest is used in function definitions to handle variable numbers of arguments.

examples.code:
const arr = [1,2,3];
const newArr = [...arr, 4, 5];
examples.description: Spread operator expands array elements into new array.
examples.whyItHappens: '...' spreads the elements individually; newArr becomes [1,2,3,4,5].

examples.code:
function sum(...nums) { return nums.reduce((a,b) => a+b, 0); }
sum(1,2,3,4);
examples.description: Rest parameter collects all arguments into array 'nums'.
examples.whyItHappens: '...nums' gathers any number of arguments passed to the function.

examples.code:
const obj1 = {a:1, b:2};
const obj2 = {...obj1, c:3};
examples.description: Spread operator copies properties into new object.
examples.whyItHappens: '...' expands key-value pairs from obj1 into obj2.

javascript.title: Destructuring (array & object)
javascript.content: Destructuring allows extracting values from arrays or objects into distinct variables in a concise syntax. Array destructuring uses position, while object destructuring uses property names. Default values can be provided during destructuring.

examples.code:
const arr = [1,2,3];
const [x, y] = arr;
examples.description: Array destructuring assigns 1 to x and 2 to y.
examples.whyItHappens: Positions in array match the variable order in destructuring.

examples.code:
const obj = {a:10, b:20};
const {a, b} = obj;
examples.description: Object destructuring assigns properties 'a' and 'b' to variables.
examples.whyItHappens: Variable names match object property names for assignment.

examples.code: const {a, c=30} = obj;
examples.description: Default value 30 assigned to c since 'c' property does not exist in obj.
examples.whyItHappens: Provides fallback when property is undefined.

javascript.title: Event Loop
javascript.content:
What is the Event Loop?

The Event Loop is a mechanism in JavaScript that continuously checks for tasks to execute, processes them one by one, and ensures that asynchronous callbacks run after the current code finishes.

What is the Call Stack?

The Call Stack is a data structure that keeps track of the functions currently being executed. When a function is called, it‚Äôs added (pushed) to the stack, and when it finishes, it‚Äôs removed (popped).

What are Macrotasks?

Macrotasks (or just ‚Äútasks‚Äù) are units of work that get queued in the task queue and run one by one after the current call stack is empty. Examples include:

  • setTimeout callbacks
  • setInterval callbacks
  • User interactions (clicks, input events)
  • Network events (like XHR or fetch responses)

What are Microtasks?

Microtasks are smaller units of work that run immediately after the current task completes, before the next macrotask starts. They have higher priority. Examples include:

  • Promise.then(), Promise.catch(), Promise.finally() callbacks
  • queueMicrotask() calls
  • MutationObserver callbacks

javascript.title: Lexical Scope & Closures
javascript.content: Lexical scope means the scope of a variable or any declaration is determined by where it is defined in the source code, not by where it is accessed. A closure is a function that remembers the variables from its outer scope even after that scope has exited. Lexical scope is static, while closures are runtime constructs that allow nested functions to retain access to variables from their lexical scope.

examples.description: Here, inner can access a because it is defined within the lexical scope of outer. Lexical scope allows inner functions to see variables from the outer function where they were defined.
examples.whyItHappens: The inner function is physically written inside outer, so it can access variables from that scope. Lexical scoping is determined at code definition time.

examples.description: The inner function forms a closure over count. Even though outer has finished executing, inner retains access to count, so each call increments the same variable.
examples.whyItHappens: Closures keep a reference to the variables of their lexical scope, allowing them to persist beyond the lifetime of the outer function.

examples.description: Using var creates a function-scoped variable i. All functions in the array share the same i, which ends at 3 after the loop. So all functions print 3.
examples.whyItHappens: var is function-scoped, so the same i is shared across all iterations. Closures capture the variable reference, not its value at the time of creation.

examples.description: let creates a block-scoped variable i. Each iteration has its own i, so each function captures the correct value in a closure.
examples.whyItHappens: Block-scoped let ensures a new i is created for each loop iteration. Each closure remembers its specific i value.

examples.description: An IIFE captures the current value of i as index for each function. This creates a closure over index, allowing each function to log the correct value.
examples.whyItHappens: The IIFE executes immediately with the current i value, so each closure retains its own copy of index instead of sharing the same variable.

examples.description: The returned object methods form closures over count. The increment method can modify count, and getCount can read it. The variable persists across multiple method calls.
examples.whyItHappens: Closures maintain access to the outer variable count, allowing it to be shared and modified across multiple function calls even after the outer function has finished.

examples.description: This example demonstrates variable hoisting, shadowing, and how this behaves differently from lexical variables. Variables declared with var are hoisted and may shadow outer variables. Inside the inner function and IIFE, this.a refers to the global object (or undefined in strict mode).
examples.whyItHappens: Hoisting moves var declarations to the top of their scope. Lexical variables are accessible according to their declaration, while this is determined by the function call context, not the lexical scope.

javascript.title: Execution Context
javascript.content:
Execution Context is the environment in which JavaScript code runs.

üëâ Types:

  • Global Execution Context (GEC): Created once at program start, holds global objects (window / global) and this.
  • Function Execution Context (FEC): Created whenever a function is invoked, each call gets its own context.
  • Eval Execution Context: Rare, discouraged.

üëâ Phases:

  • Creation Phase: Creates variable environment (hoists var, function declarations), creates lexical environment (scopes for let/const), sets up this.
  • Execution Phase: Assigns values and executes code line by line.

examples.description: Demonstrates how var is hoisted and initialized as undefined, while let is hoisted but stays in the Temporal Dead Zone until initialized.
examples.whyItHappens: In the creation phase, variables declared with var are set to undefined. let and const are hoisted too but left uninitialized, so accessing them before their declaration causes a ReferenceError.

examples.description: Within a function execution context, var is hoisted to the top of its scope as undefined, while let stays in the Temporal Dead Zone.
examples.whyItHappens: During creation, the function context hoists a (var) and b (let). But a is initialized to undefined, while b remains in TDZ until its line executes.

examples.description: Looks like console.log(x) should print 1, but it actually prints undefined. Inner prints 2.
examples.whyItHappens: Inside outer, var x is hoisted to the top of the function, shadowing the global x. So the first log is undefined (before assignment). Inner inherits that x from its lexical scope, so it prints 2.

examples.description: Prints undefined then 100.
examples.whyItHappens: a inside test is hoisted, so the first log sees it as undefined. this.a refers to the global object‚Äôs a (100 in non-strict mode). This shows the difference between variable environment and this binding.

examples.description: Prints undefined then 20.
examples.whyItHappens: Within the IIFE execution context, a is hoisted and initialized as undefined, shadowing the outer a. After assignment, a becomes 20.

examples.description: Logs undefined for a, then throws a ReferenceError for b.
examples.whyItHappens: Hoisting puts a into memory as undefined, but b is hoisted into TDZ. Attempting to access it before declaration triggers a ReferenceError.

examples.description: Prints 30 then 10.
examples.whyItHappens: The innermost a shadows outer ones. this.a points to global a (10) because inner() is called as a plain function (not as a method). This tests understanding of both execution context and this.

examples.description: Prints the function definition, not undefined or 'assigned'.
examples.whyItHappens: Function declarations are hoisted before variables. So during creation, foo is first bound to the function. Later, var foo is hoisted but ignored since it‚Äôs already declared. Only after execution, foo becomes 'assigned'.

javascript.title: Objects in JavaScript
javascript.content:
Objects in JavaScript are collections of key-value pairs. Keys are usually strings (or symbols), and values can be primitives, functions, or other objects. Objects allow us to model real-world entities and encapsulate related data and behavior.

In JavaScript, almost everything is an object (arrays, functions, dates, regex, etc.), except the 7 primitive types (number, bigint, string, boolean, undefined, null, symbol).

examples.description: An object literal with properties and a method. Keys are strings and values can be anything.
examples.whyItHappens: Objects group related data and behavior together, making them the building blocks for complex structures.

examples.code: const obj = { a: 1, b: 2 };
examples.description: The most common way: Object literal syntax with key-value pairs.
examples.whyItHappens: Object literals are concise and the preferred way to create simple objects.

examples.code:
const obj = new Object();
obj.a = 1;
examples.description: Using the new Object() constructor to create an empty object, then adding properties.
examples.whyItHappens: This is less common and more verbose, but functionally equivalent to object literals.

examples.description: Using a constructor function to create objects with shared structure.
examples.whyItHappens: Constructor functions (and later ES6 classes) provide a way to generate multiple similar objects efficiently.

examples.description: Using Object.create() to create a new object with a given prototype.
examples.whyItHappens: This allows explicit control over an object's prototype, making it a powerful tool for prototype-based inheritance.

examples.description: Using ES6 class syntax to create objects.
examples.whyItHappens: Classes are syntactic sugar over constructor functions + prototypes, making OOP patterns easier to read and use.

javascript.title: Property Access in Objects
javascript.content:
Property access controls how you read/write values on objects. Use dot for static keys and bracket for dynamic keys, spaces, special chars, or symbols. Optional chaining (?.) and nullish coalescing (??) make nested access safe.

  • Dot: obj.key
  • Bracket: obj[expr] where expr resolves to the key
  • Symbols: non-string unique keys
  • Optional chaining: short-circuits on null/undefined
  • "in" vs hasOwn: in checks prototype chain; Object.hasOwn() checks only own props

examples.description: Use dot for simple, bracket for computed/dynamic or special-key access.
examples.whyItHappens: Dot requires a valid identifier known at author time. Bracket evaluates an expression to a string/symbol key at runtime.

examples.description: Symbols create non-colliding keys you can only access via the same symbol reference.
examples.whyItHappens: Each Symbol value is unique; property lookups must use the exact symbol to match.

examples.description: Optional chaining prevents errors on missing links; nullish coalescing provides defaults only for null/undefined.
examples.whyItHappens: ?. stops evaluation and returns undefined if the left side is nullish; ?? returns the right side only when the left is null or undefined.

examples.description: Differentiate own vs inherited properties when checking for existence.
examples.whyItHappens: The in operator walks the prototype chain; Object.hasOwn only checks the object's own property bag.

javascript.title: Core Object Methods (keys, values, entries, fromEntries, assign)
javascript.content:
These methods help you list, transform, or merge object properties. They operate on own enumerable string-keyed props unless noted.

  • Object.keys(obj) ‚Üí string keys
  • Object.values(obj) ‚Üí values
  • Object.entries(obj) ‚Üí [[key,value],...]
  • Object.fromEntries(iter) ‚Üí entries ‚Üí object
  • Object.assign(target, ...sources) ‚Üí shallow merge
  • Object.hasOwn(obj, key) ‚Üí own-prop check

For descriptors and non-enumerables, use Object.getOwnPropertyNames, Object.getOwnPropertySymbols, Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors.

examples.description: Enumerate keys/values/pairs of own enumerable props.
examples.whyItHappens: These helpers avoid for...in pitfalls (which iterate inherited props) and return arrays suitable for iteration.

examples.description: Use entries + map + fromEntries to transform objects functionally.
examples.whyItHappens: Entries provide a list representation you can map/filter, then rebuild with fromEntries.

examples.description: assign merges sources left‚Üíright, overwriting keys; nested objects are not deep-cloned.
examples.whyItHappens: assign copies property values; if a value is an object, the reference is copied (shallow).

examples.description: Use Object.hasOwn instead of obj.hasOwnProperty to avoid shadowing issues.
examples.whyItHappens: Calling the static Object.hasOwn avoids cases where an object overrides or lacks hasOwnProperty.

typescript.title: Generics
typescript.content: Generics allow you to create reusable components that work with different types without losing type safety.
typescript.code:
function identity<T>(value: T): T { return value; }
console.log(identity<string>('Hello'));

htmlcss.title: Flexbox Basics
htmlcss.content: Flexbox is a layout mode that arranges elements in a row or column, distributing space evenly.
htmlcss.code: .container { display: flex; justify-content: space-between; align-items: center; }

react.title: useState Hook
react.content:
useState is a React Hook that allows you to add state to function components. It returns a pair: the state variable (to read the value) and a function (to update the value). Unlike useRef, updating state with setState triggers a re-render of the component with the new state value.

Structure: const [stateVariable, setStateVariable] = useState(initialValue)

examples.description: Here, count is the state variable and setCount is the updater function. Each call to setCount triggers a re-render, showing the updated value on screen.
examples.whyItHappens: React keeps track of the state between renders using its internal hooks system. When setCount is called, React schedules a re-render with the new state value.

examples.description: Here, isOn is the state variable and setIsOn is the function to update it. The updater is called with a callback that receives the previous state.
examples.whyItHappens: React guarantees that the state update function (setIsOn) always uses the latest state. Using a callback form avoids bugs when multiple updates happen quickly.

react.title: useRef Hook
react.content: useRef is a React Hook that provides a way to persist values across re-renders without causing a re-render when the value changes. It returns a mutable object with a single property called .current. This makes it useful for two main cases: accessing DOM elements and storing mutable values that survive across renders (like instance variables in class components).

examples.description: Here, useRef is used to access a DOM element safely. The inputRef.current holds a reference to the input element, allowing us to call focus() directly.
examples.whyItHappens: React assigns the DOM node to ref.current when the element is mounted. Unlike document.getElementById, this approach is component-safe and works in React‚Äôs declarative model.

examples.description: Here, useRef is used to store a mutable value (the interval ID). It persists across re-renders but does not trigger a re-render when updated.
examples.whyItHappens: The object returned by useRef remains the same across renders. Updating .current does not cause re-renders, making it ideal for values like timers or external references.

react.title: useReducer Hook
react.content: useReducer is a React Hook used for managing complex state logic in a component. It is an alternative to useState and is particularly useful when state involves multiple sub-values or when state updates depend on the previous state. useReducer takes a reducer function and an initialState, returning a pair: the current state and a dispatch function to send actions that describe how to update the state.

examples.description: In this example, useReducer manages a simple counter. The dispatch function is used to send actions like 'increment', 'decrement', and 'reset', and the reducer returns the updated state based on the action type.
examples.whyItHappens: The reducer function is a pure function that determines how state changes in response to dispatched actions. This pattern centralizes state updates and makes complex state transitions predictable and easier to debug.

examples.description: Here, useReducer manages a form with multiple fields. The reducer handles an 'UPDATE_FIELD' action to dynamically update any form field while preserving the other fields.
examples.whyItHappens: Using a reducer for form state centralizes updates and makes it easier to manage multiple related fields. Each dispatched action carries the field name and value, and the reducer merges it with the existing state.
